New Records: Jos Buttler moved past former skipper Eoin Morgan as England's leading run-scorer in T20I cricket, with 2,468 runs.
Key Match Events: England edged past New Zealand by 20 runs.
Jos Buttler scored a sensational 73, having been twice dropped.
Glenn Phillips' magnificent 62 off 36 balls kept New Zealand in the chase until the final four overs.
Sam Curran dismissed Glenn Phillips, effectively ending New Zealand's hopes.
Buttler's excellent night continued with the gloves, taking a diving catch to dismiss Devon Conway.
Chris Woakes got the early breakthrough for England.
Ben Stokes briefly left the field after aggravating his troublesome left index finger.
Ben Stokes helped halt the avalanche of runs when he had Kane Williamson caught for a run-a-ball 40.
Sam Curran took a huge catch to dismiss the dangerous Jimmy Neesham.
Chris Woakes and Sam Curran bowled the death overs effectively, with Woakes having Daryl Mitchell caught on the long-on rope.
Phillips holed out to Chris Jordan for a superb 62 off just 36 balls.
Pre-Game Insights: When England woke up to persistent rain and leaden skies, there were fears of a washout, which would have been almost terminal for their chances of progression.
The perfect playing conditions ended up drawing a healthy crowd of 22,547 fans to the Gabba, 4,000 more than Monday's match between Australia and Ireland.
Post-Match Reflections: The result means everything rests on the final round of matches in group one, with England second, behind New Zealand and ahead of Australia on net run rate.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Earlier in the day, Sri Lanka kept their narrow hopes alive with a six-wicket victory over Afghanistan at the same venue.
Sri Lanka must beat England on Saturday and hope for other results to fall their way in order to progress.
Australia will be relying on a Sri Lanka victory should they beat Afghanistan on Friday.
Afghanistan are out of the tournament, but should they rally for a victory, or even a narrow defeat, coupled with an England victory the following day would spell the end of Australia's campaign.
